title: Green tea
desc: Unfermented tea that retains more antioxidants.

title: Black tea
desc: The most common type, which undergoes complete fermentation.

title: Mactha tea
desc: Powdered green tea used in Japanese tea ceremonies.

title: Oolong tea
desc: Partially fermented tea, somewhere between black and green.

title: Puer tea
desc: Fermented tea, which can be either raw or mature.

title: Herbal tea
desc: It does not contain tea leaves, but is made from herbs, flowers or fruits.

title: Jasmine tea
desc: Green or black tea flavoured with jasmine flowers, giving it a floral and sweet aroma.

title: Kukicha tea
desc: Japanese tea, which is a mixture of cuttings, stems and leaves of Japanese teas.

title: Rosehip tea
desc: Aromatic and rich in vitamin C herbal tea.

title: Rooibos tea
desc: A South African decaffeinated tea with a sweet, nutty flavour and rich red colour.

title: Tea with thyme
desc: A tea that has calming properties and is often used to improve digestion.

title: White tea
desc: Minimally processed tea made from young buds and leaves.

title: Cranberry tea
desc: A refreshing herbal tea with a sour taste and rich in antioxidants.

title: Hibiscus tea
desc: Bright red herbal tea with a sour taste, rich in antioxidants and vitamins.

title: Lavender tea
desc: A herbal tea with a floral aroma, known for its relaxing properties.
